newsitem.title: DENMARK: SOCCER-CLEMENTE SAYS REFEREEING MISTAKES ARE BIGGEST PROBLEM.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-CLEMENTE SAYS REFEREEING MISTAKES ARE BIGGEST PROBLEM.

text.p: International soccer's biggest problem is refereeing mistakes, Spain coach Javier Clemente said on Tuesday.

"The big problem is refereeing mistakes. You need perfect referees, but where is the perfect referee?" Clemente said during a break on the second day of the three-day UEFA National Coaches Convention held by European soccer's governing body.
But Clemente, whose side were eliminated by hosts England on penalties in the Euro 96 quarter-finals in June, said perfection in football was not a good thing.
He said he did not favour the introduction of technology as a means of reducing the chances of mistakes by referees, such as televised slow-motion replays.
"In my opinion, technology must not come into football, because then the arguments will end and without arguments football will die.
"We would lose the great attraction of football, that a modest team can upset a big team," he said.

Euro 96 suffered from several glaring mistakes by referees including an apparently valid goal scored by Spanish striker Julio Salinas against England which was disallowed and a penalty awarded to the Czech Republic in the final against Germany for a foul which video replays showed was a metre outside the box.
Clemente said he was against tampering with the laws of football as a means of encouraging a more attacking game and settling matches which ended drawn after extra time.
"The golden goal can be a traumatic experience, but then it also has its good side," Clemente said.
"A replay would be ideal but there isn't space in a major competition lasting a short time."
Clemente said the game's authorities were always looking to make football more dynamic and that this was central to discussions at the convention.
"Some time back we got to 23 effective minutes of play in 45 minutes, now it's up to 31. Ruling that the goalkeeper mustn't handle a back pass has contributed to this," he said.
"The idea is that we should play more. But we'll still be 11 against 11 next year."
